text: Hi everybody and welcome to our module on the cell cycle.
Shown on the screen is the cell cycle.
You can find this kind of drawing in most cell biology textbooks and it shows the phases
that a cell goes through as it grows and then divides to become two daughter cells.
So if we start at this point right here, this is right after a cell has divided.
At this point, cells enter what is known as the G1 phase and the letter G is for growth.
This is the first growth phase and hence it is called G1.
After G1 cells will enter the S phase, this is where they begin synthesizing DNA.
There's then a shorter growth phase called the G2 phase and this is followed by the M phase
which is when mytosis occurs and the cell divides into two daughter cells.
In addition, some cells will exit the G1 phase and enter a quiescent phase known as G0.
They will then sometimes go back into the G1 phase and then proceed through the rest of the phases.
And then finally, I've cleared away my ink so I can show you that sometimes the cell cycle
is divided into just two phases.
The M phase is mytosis when the cell divides and this entire phase where the cell is not
dividing is called interface that includes all the time that the cell spends in G1, G0,
S or G2.
On this slide, I've summarized the key points about the cell cycle.
The second phase is when growth can occur during the G1 phase, there is growth followed
by the S phase where DNA synthesis occurs, followed by the second growth phase G2.
Cells can exit the G1 phase to enter the G0 resting phase and then they can exit the G0 phase
and go back to G1.
Then the M phase is when mytosis occurs and the cell divides into two daughter cells.
Now we'll go through each of the phases of the cell cycle in a little bit more detail.
In the G1 phase, synthesis of proteins and cellular organelles occurs.
The length of this phase is variable depending on conditions.
If cells want to grow rapidly, this can be a very short phase and other situations.
This can be a longer phase.
Mydogens are extra cellular signaling molecules that are usually proteins that stimulate cell
division.
They function via molecules called cyclandependent kinases, which we'll talk about in a minute.
In just some vocabulary here, a growth factor is a factor that stimulates growth in size.
A mydogen is a factor that stimulates growth via cell division by driving cells through
the cell cycle.
Now some molecules are both mydogens and growth factors and the terms are often used interchangeably,
but the technical definition is that mydogens drive cell division and growth factors drive
growth in cell size.
As I mentioned before, in the S phase, there is synthesis of DNA.
Models will become a chromosome with two sister chromatids.
In the G2 phase, there is a short growth phase and preparation for mitosis.
Now let's talk about the G0 or resting phase.
This phase often occurs when there is an absence of mydogen stimulation of cells.
It is a specialized non-dividing state.
It turns out that most cells in our body are in G0.
Most cells in our body are not in the process of dividing.
In fact, some are in permanent G0 state.
Others go in and out.
For example, neurons in skeletal muscle cells are in a permanent resting G0 state.
They are said to be terminally differentiated.
They do not divide into daughter cells.
Liver cells are usually in a G0 state, but they can divide if stimulated.
You may know that the liver is a very regenerative organ and if there is damage, liver cells can
begin to divide and regrow the liver.
Fibroblast and lymphocytes can enter and exit G0 many times in their lifespan.
They are often in a resting state, but when they are stimulated, they can begin to divide.
And then cells in the bone marrow and GI epithelial cells and hair follicle cells are considered
labile cells.
The word labile means rapidly changing.
These cells are rapidly dividing and therefore they rarely or never enter the G0 phase.
And for this reason, these are the cell types that are most commonly affected by chemotherapy.
In the hematology section in the videos on chemotherapy drugs, I talk about these drugs
which target rapidly dividing cells.
This is helpful because they kill cancer cells, but these drugs also have adverse effects
on these types of cells because they are rapidly dividing and are rarely in the G0 phase.
And that's why side effects of many chemotherapy agents include bone marrow suppression, GI
upset and loss of hair.
Now let's talk about mitosis.
This is the shortest or most rapid portion of the cell cycle.
It's usually divided into five phases called pro phase, pro meta phase, meta phase, antifase
and teal phase.
And we'll go through all these in the next few slides.
The chromosomes in the nucleus of cells is usually relatively spread out and this is
helpful so that DNA can be transcribed.
However, when cells enter mitosis, the first phase to enter is pro phase and in this phase
the chromosomes begin to condense and pull together.
In addition, an important structure called the mitotic spindle begins to form.
This structure is made up of fibers of microtubules that will eventually pull the chromosomes
apart into two daughter cells.
In pro meta phase, the chromosomes begin to organize on the mitotic spindle.
This is a picture of pro meta phase shown in the screen here.
And then the hallmark of meta phase is that the chromosomes line up in the middle of the
cell as shown in this picture here.
They are lined up on what's known as the meta phase plate.
From here they are going to eventually be pulled apart to opposite ends of the cell.
And then in anaphase, the chromosomes separate to opposite ends of the cell.
Remember in the S phase, the chromosomes are replicated into two sister chromatids.
Those chromatids are now pulled to opposite ends of the cell in anaphase.
And then finally in tealaphase, the spindle breaks down and the cell begins to divide that's
called cytokinesis.
And then you are left with two daughter cells that came originally from one single cell.
Everything I've talked about up until now is pretty basic.
You may have had it in a college biology course.
But what you might be less familiar with and what it's very important you understand for
the USMLE step one exam is how cells control progression through the cell cycle.
Those in a body regulate progression through the cell cycle by regulating progression through
checkpoints.
These are important parts of the cell cycle also called restriction points that the cell
does not move beyond unless conditions are just right.
So for example, the G1 to S phase transition, just prior to S phase entry is a very important
checkpoint.
So is the G2 to M phase transition just prior to mitosis.
In addition there is an important checkpoint within the M phase itself prior to anaphase
and cytokinesis.
And what the cell does is look at various regulatory elements and it arrests itself if conditions
are not appropriate.
In other words, it does not proceed further in the cell cycle if conditions are not just
right.
And in particular the first checkpoint in late G1 at the G1 to S phase transition is very
important because this is where the cell commits to proceeding into the cell cycle and growing.
In other words, once the cell moves beyond this checkpoint it is entering the S phase
and beginning to synthesize new DNA and therefore it is committing to dividing into two
daughter cells.
So the first thing to be aware of about all of these checkpoints is that they depend on
cycle and dependent kinases which I mentioned before.
These are the central components of cell cycle control.
They are kinase enzymes which means that they lead to phosphorylation of other proteins.
Any kinase enzyme phosphorylate something else.
And they are always present in the cell but they are inactive.
So in other words, they are waiting to drive the cell through the cell cycle but they are
inactive and they need other molecules called cyclons in order to become active.
Therefore this means that cyclons are regulatory proteins that activate the cycle and dependent
kinases.
And cyclon CDK complexes phosphorylate regulatory proteins and they allow cells to progress
through the phases of the cell cycle.
There are many different classes and subtypes of cyclons that have been described and all
of their levels vary during the cell cycle.
Shown on the screen is a picture you can find in many cell biology textbooks.
This is the G1 phase on the left.
Here is S phase G2 in mitosis and you can see that levels of the various cyclons are going
up and down and when the level goes up that cyclon will activate a cyclon dependent kinase
and that will drive the cell through the next phase of the cell cycle.
So now let's focus on the very important G1 to S phase checkpoint.
Remember this is when the cell commits to DNA synthesis and cell division.
So during the G1 phase cyclon dependent kinase activity is suppressed but mitogens can
activate cyclon dependent kinases and drive entry into the S phase.
The way they do this is by interacting with cell surface receptors.
This will activate intracellular pathways and increase G1 cyclon levels and those G1
cyclons will increase cyclon dependent kinase activity.
In the G1 to S phase checkpoint cyclon CDK complexes activate proteins called E2F proteins.
These are transcription factors that bind to DNA promoter regions and activate genes
that are necessary for entry into the S phase.
Now E2F proteins are normally inhibited and the reason they are inhibited is because
they are bound to molecules known as retinoblastoma proteins.
This inhibition is released by the G1 to S phase CDK phosphorylation of retinoblastoma proteins.
I'll show you a picture of that in a minute.
What this means is that retinoblastoma proteins regulate cell growth and therefore they are
called tumor suppressor proteins.
So here's a picture to make this very easy for you to understand.
Normally the E2F proteins are inactive and the reason they are inactive is because
retinoblastoma proteins which are active are bound to the E2F transcription factors.
When cyclon CDK complexes come in they can phosphorylate the retinoblastoma proteins.
This will release the retinoblastoma proteins from E2F and then the E2F transcription factors
can go and drive cell growth.
So the retinoblastoma proteins in the E2F transcription factors are one element of the G1 to S
checkpoint but there is another important element of this checkpoint that has to do with DNA
damage.
If DNA damage occurs in the G1 phase this can arrest cell division and prevent progression
into the S phase.
This allows time for repair and it prevents the development of mutant cells or
cancer cells that have abnormal genes.
What this means is that DNA damage has its own ability
to initiate signaling pathways that affect whether or not a cell proceeds beyond the G1 to S checkpoint.
There are two pathways by which a cell can become arrested at the G1 to S phase checkpoint
if DNA damage has occurred.
The first one is called the ATM pathway.
This pathway is activated
by double stranded breaks in DNA.
ATM stands for ataxia-talangectasia mutated and it gets this name
because the ATM gene is mutated in the disorder ataxia-talangectasia which I discuss in the neurology
section in the video on the cerebellum.
The other pathways called the ATR pathway, this pathway is
activated by single stranded breaks in DNA.
Both pathways lead to phosphorylation of proteins and
via phosphorylation of proteins.
Both pathways can cause cell cycle and growth arrest if there is
DNA damage in the G1 phase.
The P53 protein is the major target of the ATM and ATR systems.
It becomes phosphorylated when there is DNA damage and this prevents breakdown of the P53 protein
and increases its levels and activity.
Basically the P53 protein easily falls apart unless there is
DNA damage and then it becomes stabilized.
When P53 is stabilized it induces transcription of a
protein called P21.
P21 can bind to cycle independent kinases and inhibit their activity and
remember it is these kinases that allow progression through the cell cycle.
When they are inhibited this
will block cell progression through the cell cycle.
What this means is that both P53 and P21 are
considered tumor suppressors because they prevent abnormal cell growth.
Once again I'll use a picture
to make this very clear.
When there is DNA damage the P53 protein which is normally unstable and
rapidly breaks down becomes stabilized.
It can then go and promote transcription of the P21 gene which
will lead to synthesis of the P21 protein and the P21 protein can inhibit cycle independent
kinases and lead to growth arrest.
Just to tie this into what we talked about before,
earlier I showed you how cycle and CDK complexes can release the inhibition of E2F so that E2F
can go and promote cell growth.
What P21 does is block this process and it prevents cell growth
and therefore the cell does not proceed through the G1 to S phase checkpoint and therefore does
not continue growing and dividing.
Here I've made a summary slide just to make this very clear.
The G1S checkpoint is very important because that's where the cell commits to DNA synthesis and
cell division.
If there is mitogen stimulation via the retinoblastoma E2F pathway that can drive
the cell from the G1 into the S phase past the G1S checkpoint.
On the other hand if there is
DNA damage at any point during the G1 phase via the P53 pathway this can arrest the cell in the G1
phase.
I'll finish this video with a couple of clinical correlations.
Retinoblastoma is a rare
childhood eye malignancy and it is caused by mutations in the RB1 gene which codes for retinoblastoma
protein.
So children born with this gene mutation have abnormal retinoblastoma protein and that leads
to unregulated cell growth via the E2F pathway.
Remember the job of retinoblastoma protein is to
inhibit E2F so when the RB protein is abnormal E2F is free to do its job and that leads to
unregulated cell growth.
Another clinical correlation is the Lee Froumini syndrome.
This is a
very rare syndrome where patients develop multiple malignancies at an early age.
It's sometimes called
the SBLA cancer syndrome because some of the tumors that develop are sarcoma breast leukemia and
adrenal gland tumors.
This condition is caused by mutations in the tumor suppressor gene TP53
which codes for the P53 protein.
So when there is a mutation in this gene P53 is not normal
and therefore the cell cycle is not arrested to allow for DNA repair in G1.
This can lead to
accumulation of DNA damage basically the cell progresses through the cell cycle
despite having abnormal DNA and this can lead to malignancies in many different organ systems.
And that concludes our module on the cell cycle.
Hi everyone and welcome to our module on DNA replication.
DNA contains our genetic code.
It's found in the nucleus of eukaryotic cells like human cells.
It's found in the cytoplasm of pro-carotic cells like those of bacteria.
And in order for our cell to divide, it needs to replicate or copy its DNA so that when
the cell splits into two daughter cells, each cell can have a copy of the genetic code.
I discussed DNA structure in detail in a video in the biochemistry section, but I'll
just briefly review some key points here that are relevant to our discussion of DNA replication.
So DNA is double stranded and each strand has a ribose sugar backbone as shown in this
picture made up of ribose sugar units.
Those ribose sugars are connected to one another by a phosphate group and then each ribose
sugar contains nitrogenous base and the four bases found in DNA are adenine and thymine,
guanine and cytosine.
The bases in DNA pair with one another linking the two strands together and adenine always
pairs with thymine as shown in this picture on the right and guanine always pairs with cytosine.
In RNA molecules, there is no thymine.
Instead there's a base called ureosil and so ureosil takes the place of thymine and
pairs with adenine, guanine still pairs with cytosine in RNA.
And if you look at this double strand of DNA on the right here, you'll notice that this
strand here ends in a phosphate group at the top.
That's called the five prime end of that strand.
The other end of the strand is a hydroxyl group hanging off the ribose sugar that's called
the three prime end.
On the other side, it goes in the opposite direction.
The five prime end is at the bottom and the three prime end is at the top.
And this is called the antiparallel structure of DNA and this will be important as we
talk about how DNA is replicated.
Neucleotides are the building blocks of DNA.
DNA is a polymer made up of repeating nucleotide monomer units.
At the top right side of the screen is an example of a nucleotide.
It contains three pieces and a troginous base, a ribose sugar and a phosphate group.
Neucleotides are synthesized as mono phosphates with just one phosphate group like this example
on the top right side of the screen.
They are then converted to a tri-phosphate form like at the bottom where three phosphate
groups are attached.
And it is this tri-phosphate form that is added to growing strands of DNA in DNA replication.
So for example, at the bottom of the screen is a molecule of deoxyadenazine tri-phosphate.
If this is added to a growing strand of DNA, these two phosphate groups will be cut
off.
The one phosphate group will remain and will link this monomer into the polymer of a growing
DNA strand.
Okay, so now that we've reviewed those basics of DNA structure, let's get into DNA replication.
So shown on the screen is my own model of a double strand of DNA.
I've got one strand going all in the bottom with a three-prime end here and a five-prime
end here.
Antiparallel to that, I have another strand at the top with the three-prime end here and

And the nucleotides are all paired according to their nitrogenous bases, so adenosine always

The big picture of how this works is that the two strands will separate and then two new
strands will be synthesized and thus the cell will go from having one double-stranded
piece of DNA to having two double-stranded pieces of DNA.
So what we'll start going through now are the details of how that process occurs.
And the first thing you should know is that DNA replication begins at specific sites
called origins of replication and we'll talk more about what's unique about these sites

The enzyme that separates or unwinds the double strand of DNA is called DNA helicase.

And then there are other important players in separated two strands called single-stranded

They stabilize the single strands of DNA for DNA replication.
And I've summarized these points on this slide here.
The helicase enzyme unwinds and opens the double helix.
It hydroizes ATP to carry out this role.
Single-stranded binding proteins assist the helicase.
They stabilize and straighten single strands of DNA.
Let's talk a little bit more about the origin of replication.
These origins of replication occur at specific DNA sequences that are able to attract DNA
replication initiator proteins and that are also easy to unwind and open.
If you look over at this drawing of DNA on the right, you'll notice that there are
three bonds between guanine and cytosine bases.
There are only two bonds, however, between adenine and thymine.
This means it's easier to unwind DNA in places where there's lots of adenine and thymine.
And indeed, that's where many origins of replication occur.
These are called AT-rich sequences.
They're easy to open because there are fewer bonds between adenine and thymine.
Once the double helix has been opened up, the major enzyme that synthesizes new strands

And there are a number of these enzymes.
In bacteria or prokaryotes, there are four versions of DNA polymerase number one through

DNA polymerase three is the major DNA polymerase that synthesizes new strands of DNA.
Polymerase one removes RNA primers.
We'll talk about RNA primers in a minute, but there are another important component of

In eukaryotic and human cells, the DNA polymerases are alpha beta, gamma, delta, and epsilon.

The others are in the nucleus and perform various functions in synthesizing new DNA strands.
So now let's talk about primers.
It turns out that DNA polymerase cannot initiate replication on its own.
In other words, it cannot all by itself start to build a new strand of DNA.
Instead, it requires a short starter portion of DNA called a primer.
This is a short nucleotide sequence.
This allows DNA polymerase to begin making a new chain.
The primers are formed at the point of initiation of a new chain, and they are required by DNA polymerase

And there's an important distinction here between DNA polymerase and RNA polymerase, which

RNA polymerase does not require a primer, and we'll talk more about RNA polymerase in the

The enzyme that makes primers is appropriately named DNA primase.
And what's interesting about primers is that even though they're used to synthesize DNA,

RNA is different from DNA in that it is made up of ribonucleotides, not deoxyribonucleotides.
If you look at the bottom of the screen, a ribonucleotide has a hydroxyl in this position

In addition, as we discussed previously, RNA has uracil instead of the base thymine.
Eventually, these RNA primers will be removed and replaced with DNA, but they are used to

So here's a simplified picture that you can keep in your mind to understand how this process
works.
The primer binds here at the three prime end of one of the strands at the origin of replication.
This will allow DNA polymerase to then begin adding nucleotides so that it can replicate
this upper strand here.
So that brings me to an important concept called the directionality of DNA synthesis in order

Let's imagine that these four nucleotides I've placed on the screen are linked together

So we've got a strand of DNA with a C, A, T, and G sequence.
Let's imagine that DNA polymerase would like to add an adenosine to this DNA strand.
Well nucleotides are always added in their triphosphate form, so this is adenosine triphosphate,
and it's ready to be added to this strand.
What DNA polymerase will do is break this phosphate bond here, and that will create the energy

So the way you can understand the directionality of DNA synthesis is to appreciate that all the
energy comes from right here.
In other words, it's like there's a little bit of heat around this phosphate bond that

Well, the only place the phosphate bond goes is down here at the three prime end.
It would not link to this phosphate group here at the five prime end.
So what this means is that DNA polymerase will always add nucleotides to the three prime

So if DNA polymerase were to add that A to our growing strand, we would go from four

So the key point here that you want to remember is that DNA replication or DNA synthesis always

Another way to look at this is that nucleotides are always added to the three prime end of
the growing strand, and that's because that's where the phosphate group fits, and the phosphate

So if we go back to our replication fork here, the primer has been put down here.
This is the three prime end of the template that we're using to make new DNA, which means

So this is the five prime end of the primer, and this is the three prime end of the primer.
And as we discussed, nucleotides are always added to the three prime end.
So what's going to happen here is DNA polymerase is going to add another base, another base,

Now that works fine for the top strand, but in the bottom strand, the orientation is opposite.
So the five prime end of the primer is over here, and the three prime end is over here.
This means that in the case of the bottom strand, the primer has to bind closer to the

So therefore, DNA polymerase on the bottom strand will add molecules like this to synthesize

Now let's talk about what happens as DNA continues to be unwound in the replication fork

For the top strand, this creates no significant problems for DNA polymerase.
Nucleotides can continue to be laid down as the replication fork widens.
For the bottom strand, however, there's a problem.
DNA polymerase has already used the primer that was laid down to synthesize a new molecule
all the way to the end of the old molecule.
What this means is a new primer must be laid down, which DNA polymerase can use to synthesize
DNA all the way up to the first primer, and thus the DNA synthesis in the strand on the

And that's because of the different three prime and five prime orientations of the top

And here's a picture from the web just to pull all this together.
The top strand is called the leading strand.
It is oriented from three prime to five prime, and thus it only requires a single primer,

The bottom strand is called the lagging strand.
It is oriented from five prime to three prime.

There are a number of primers.

This enzyme creates phosphodiester bonds.

There's one more player in this process we need to discuss, and that is the enzyme topo

This enzyme prevents DNA tangling.
As DNA is being unwound, it can get knotted up and tangled as shown at the bottom left

Topo isomerase enzymes relieve that nodding and tension and tangling in DNA.
The way they do this is by breaking the DNA and then resealing it to relieve the tensions

And this disrupts cells that are rapidly dividing like cancer cells.
Let me make a couple general key points about DNA replication.

So leading strand DNA replication is continuous as I showed before, but lagging strand replication

That involves the okazaki fragments and DNA ligase enzyme to link those okazaki fragments

DNA replication is referred to as semi-conservative.
The reason it's called this is because the new DNA strand contains one old and one new

So for example, if we start with a double-stranded piece of DNA, the strands will separate

Now that we've discussed DNA replication, let's talk about proofreading.

Just to make this point very clear, let's go back to our drawing of a replication fork.

The enzyme takes a piece of RNA and uses it as a template to synthesize a piece of DNA,

So this is where telomere will come in and bind.
Telomere has an RNA template as part of the enzyme, which can bind to the telomere and

You can imagine that in cells with absent or low levels of the telomerase enzyme, after

For some cells, this is a big problem because they need to divide indefinitely and so

Hi everybody and welcome to our module on polymerase chain reaction.
Polymerase chain reaction or PCR is a laboratory technique whereby DNA molecules in a sample
are amplified or copied to make multiple copies of DNA.
This has a number of uses.
For example, you can make more DNA from a very small amount in a sample.
In addition, you can use PCR to determine if DNA is present by seeing if it amplifies
via this technique.
Then finally, you can also determine the amount of DNA by seeing how quickly it amplifies.
If you start with lots of DNA, it will amplify rapidly.
